title: Blog POST TWO
author: Post two
description: This is the blog post tutorial one
body:
<!--StartFragment-->

He was born Leo Marcellus in[Thracia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thracia "Thracia")or in[Dacia Aureliana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dacia_Aureliana "Dacia Aureliana")province in the year 401 to a[Thraco-Roman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thraco-Roman "Thraco-Roman")family.[\[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFriell1998170,_261-5)His Dacian origin[\[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFriell1998170-6)is mentioned by[Candidus Isaurus](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Candidus_Isaurus&action=edit&redlink=1 "Candidus Isaurus (page does not exist)"),[\[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBury1958315-7)[\[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-8)while[John Malalas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Malalas "John Malalas")believes that he was of[Bessian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bessian "Bessian")stock.[\[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBury1958315-7)[\[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-9)He served in the[Roman army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_army "Roman army"), rising to the rank of*[comes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comes "Comes")*. Leo was the last of a series of emperors placed on the throne by[Aspar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aspar "Aspar"), the[Alan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alans "Alans")serving as commander-in-chief of the army, who thought Leo would be an easy[puppet ruler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puppet_ruler "Puppet ruler"). Instead, Leo became more and more independent from Aspar, causing tension that would culminate in the assassination of the latter.

Leo's[coronation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronation "Coronation")as emperor on 7 February 457,[\[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-10)[\[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBury1958-1)was the first known to involve the[Patriarch of Constantinople](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarch_of_Constantinople "Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople").[\[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-11)Leo I made an alliance with the[Isaurians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isauria "Isauria")and was thus able to eliminate Aspar. The price of the alliance was the marriage of Leo's daughter to Tarasicodissa, leader of the Isaurians, who, as[Zeno](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeno_(emperor) "Zeno (emperor)"), became emperor in 474. In 469, Aspar attempted to assassinate Zeno[\[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-12)and very nearly succeeded. Finally, in 471, Aspar's son[Ardabur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardabur_(consul_447) "Ardabur (consul 447)")was implicated in a plot against Leo but was killed by palace[eunuchs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eunuch "Eunuch")acting on Leo's orders.[\[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-13)

Leo sometimes overestimated his abilities and made mistakes that threatened the internal order of the Empire. The[Balkans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balkan_peninsula "Balkan peninsula")were ravaged by the[Ostrogoths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ostrogoths "Ostrogoths"), after a disagreement between the Emperor and the young chief[Theodoric the Great](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodoric_the_Great "Theodoric the Great"), who had been raised at Leo's court in Constantinople, where he was steeped in Roman government and military tactics. There were also some raids by the[Huns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huns "Huns"). However, these attackers were unable to take[Constantinople](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople")thanks to the[walls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walls_of_Constantinople "Walls of Constantinople"), which had been rebuilt and reinforced in the reign of[Theodosius II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theodosius_II "Theodosius II")and against which they possessed no suitable[siege engines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_engine "Siege engine").

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Solidus-Leo_I-RIC_0605.7.jpg/300px-Solidus-Leo_I-RIC_0605.7.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Solidus-Leo_I-RIC_0605.7.jpg)

[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Solidus-Leo_I-RIC_0605.7.jpg "Enlarge")

Gold[solidus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solidus_(coin) "Solidus (coin)")of Leo I, struck 462–473 AD at Constantinople.

Leo's reign was also noteworthy for his influence in the[Western Roman Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire "Western Roman Empire"), marked by his appointment of[Anthemius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthemius "Anthemius")as[Western Roman Emperor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Roman_Emperor "Western Roman Emperor")in 467. He attempted to build on this political achievement with an expedition against the[Vandals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandals "Vandals")in 468, which was defeated due to the arrogance of Leo's brother-in-law[Basiliscus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basiliscus "Basiliscus"). This disaster drained the Empire of men and money.[Procopius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procopius "Procopius")estimated the costs of the expedition to be 130,000 pounds of gold;[John the Lydian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_the_Lydian "John the Lydian")estimated the costs to be 65,000 pounds of gold and 750,000 pounds of silver.[\[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-14)The expedition consisted of 1,113 ships carrying 100,000 men; 600 of these ships were lost during the expedition. After this defeat, the Vandals raided Greek coasts until a costly peace agreement was signed between Leo and Genseric.

Leo became very unpopular in his last days as Emperor for abolishing any non-religious celebration or event on Sundays.[*[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]

Leo died of[dysentery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dysentery "Dysentery")at the age of 73 on 18 January 474.

## Marriage and children[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Leo_I_the_Thracian&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Marriage and children")]

Leo and Verina had three children. Their eldest daughter[Ariadne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariadne_(empress) "Ariadne (empress)")was born prior to the death of[Marcian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcian "Marcian")(reigned 450 – 457).[\[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-15)Ariadne had a younger sister,[Leontia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leontia_(daughter_of_Leo_I) "Leontia (daughter of Leo I)"). Leontia was first betrothed to[Patricius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patricius_(Caesar) "Patricius (Caesar)"), a son of Aspar, but their engagement was probably annulled when Aspar and another of his sons, Ardabur, were assassinated in 471.[*[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*]Leontia then married[Marcian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcian_(usurper) "Marcian (usurper)"), a son of Emperor[Anthemius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthemius "Anthemius")and[Marcia Euphemia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcia_Euphemia "Marcia Euphemia"). The couple led a failed revolt against Zeno in 478–479. They were exiled to[Isauria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isauria "Isauria")following their defeat.[\[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-ReferenceA-16)

An unknown son was born in 463. He died five months following his birth. The only sources about him are a[horoscope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horoscope "Horoscope")by[Rhetorius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhetorius "Rhetorius")and a[hagiography](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hagiography "Hagiography")of[Daniel the Stylite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_the_Stylite "Daniel the Stylite").[\[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-ReferenceA-16)

The*Georgian Chronicle*, a 13th-century compilation drawing from earlier sources, reports a marriage of[Vakhtang I of Iberia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vakhtang_I_of_Iberia "Vakhtang I of Iberia")to Princess Helena of Byzantium, identifying her as a daughter of the predecessor of Zeno.[\[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_the_Thracian#cite_note-17)This predecessor was probably Leo I, the tale attributing a third daughter to Leo.[Cyril Toumanoff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyril_Toumanoff "Cyril Toumanoff")identified two children of this marriage: Mithridates of Iberia; and Leo of Iberia. This younger Leo was father of[Guaram I of Iberia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guaram_I_of_Iberia "Guaram I of Iberia"). The accuracy of the descent is unknown.
